indicating the onset of an earthquake and provide extra seconds of early
warning. Cynthia Graber...

The Times hired her in 1995. She became science editor in 2011.

articles.summary:
When it comes to cats, those meows mean... well, a lot of things.With each
purr, yowl or even blink, felines are saying, "Hello," ''Let's snuggle" or
"Beat it, mum." For the increasing number of pet owners who want to connect
with...
articles.title: Cats chat with us through meows, blinks and roving whiskers (APN)

articles.summary:
Traumatic events during childhood, as well as growing up with abuse, neglect
or a dysfunctional family, may increase the risk of developing high blood
pressure later in life, a small study suggests


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Childhood Trauma Linked to High Blood Pressure Later in Life (Scientific American)

articles.author: Guardian: None Given
articles.summary:
Guardian: The first public hearings will take place in the Hague on Tuesday in
the first case in the world to use existing human rights and tort law to hold
a government responsible for failing to reduce carbon emissions fast enough.
The 886 citizens involved in the class action against the Dutch government aim
to force it to take more robust action to reduce emissions. They also hope to
offer a legal solution to the political impasse on international climate
change action. They will ask the judiciary...
articles.title: Dutch Govn't Facing Legal Action Over Failure to Curb Carbon Emissions (climateark)

articles.summary: The smallest particle counter weighs only 195 grams
articles.title: Envitems Launches The World's Smallest Particle Counter (24-7 Pressrelease)

articles.summary:
PACIFICA, Calif. (AP) -- When a 50-foot sperm whale washed ashore on a beach
south of San Francisco, people stopped to look, snapped pictures of the
massive mammal and even reached out and touched the creature that looks more
like a dark ocean rock than the largest tooth predator on earth....
articles.title: Experts remove whale carcass near San Francisco (The Arizona Republic)

articles.author: Jennifer Viegas
articles.summary:
The discovery that female chimps stab prey with handcrafted spears suggests
how the earliest humans first made weapons and hunted.
articles.title: Female Chimps Seen Making, Wielding Spears (Discovery)

articles.summary:
For every 1,000 mothers who develop gestational diabetes by 26 weeks, seven
children may develop autism spectrum disorders, a study finds


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Pregnancy-Related Diabetes Has Possible Link to Autism (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
Mitochondrial disorders, rooted in malfunctions within tiny cellular power
plants, are notoriously complex, with few effective treatments. But by using
existing human drugs to improve metabolism in microscopic worms, scientists
have set the stage for clinical trials of possible innovative therapies for
mitochondrial disease.
articles.title: Restoring cellular energy signals may treat mitochondrial diseases in humans (Eurekalert)

articles.summary: Labs don't yet exist, but the technology has come a long way.
articles.title: Scientists Prepare to Study Samples from Mars (Discover Magazine)

articles.author: Mia Tramz
articles.summary: It is also the first color image snapped from an approaching spacecraft
articles.title: See the Closest Color Photo of Pluto Ever Taken (TIME)

articles.author: Ken Kremer
articles.summary:
KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, FL - After a 24 hour delay due to threatening clouds, a
SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket soared spectacularly to orbit from the Florida Space
coast today, April 14, carrying a Dragon on a science supply run bound for the
the International Space Station that will help pave the way for deep space [â€¦]
articles.title: SpaceX Dragon Launches on Science Supply Run to Station, Booster Hard Lands on Barge (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
The neural network necessary for normal face recognition has been not fully
understood yet until now. Here, the research group of Dr. Daisuke Matsuyoshi
(present affiliation: The University of Tokyo) led by Prof. Ryusuke Kakigi and
Prof. Norihiro Sadato of the National Institute for Physiological Sciences
(NIPS), National Institutes of Natural Sciences (NINS), by using the
functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), revealed that suppression of the
brain area responsible for object recognition by that for face recognition is
necessarily for "normal face" recognition. The researchers simulated
mathematically networks between the brain areas and showed that not only brain
areas that execute face recognition but also brain areas that had been
considered non-essential to face recognition are important for "normal face"
recognition. This result was published in The Journal of Neuroscience, the
weekly official journal of the Society for Neuroscience, Washington, DC.
articles.title: The neural network necessary for 'normal face' recognition (Biologynews)

articles.summary:
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. (Reuters) - The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration
will carefully review an Orbital ATK-led investigation into an October rocket
explosion to ensure that all possible causes were properly considered, a top
FAA official said Wednesday.
articles.title: U.S. FAA says plans careful look at Orbital report on rocket blast (reuters)
